Description.description: A user-facing markdown description of the item, consisting of one or more paragraphs.
Description.title: Description

Display.description: Data relevant to this item's display/rendering.
Display.title: Display

$id.description: The item's unique string ID. Any object that contains a localizable user-facing string *must* have this key.
$id.title: $id

Optional.description: Whether or not the source material presents this rules item as optional.
Optional.title: Optional

Text.description: The item's rules text as a markdown string.
Text.title: Text

Suggestions.description: "Non-canonical" suggestions of related items. They might be convenient to present to the user, but in most implementations rolling them automatically is not recommended.
Suggestions.title: Suggestions

Asset.description: The ID of the parent Asset of the move, if any.
Asset.title: Asset

Progress move.description: Whether or not the move is a Progress Move. Progress moves roll two challenge dice against a progress score.
Progress move.title: Progress move

Variant of.description: The ID of the move that this move is a variant of, if any.
Variant of.title: Variant of

Oracles.description: The IDs of any oracles directly referenced by the move, or vice versa.
Oracles.title: Oracles

$id.description: The item's unique string ID. Any object that contains a localizable user-facing string *must* have this key.
$id.title: $id

Category.description: The ID of the move's category.
Category.title: Category

Display.description: Data relevant to this item's display/rendering.
Display.title: Display

Optional.description: Whether or not the source material presents this rules item as optional.
Optional.title: Optional

Canonical.description:
The title of this item, which here is defined as the associated header text *exactly* as it appears on the page.

For items that represent a single table column, this is the label that appears at the top of the column.

Use this title if you want high fidelity to the book. For most interactive UX, it's recommended to use {@link Title.Standard} instead.
Canonical.title: Canonical

Short.description:
The shortest title for this item that remains distinct amongst its siblings.

Unless you're very pressed for space, most UX should use {@link Title.Standard} instead.
Short.title: Short

Standard.description:
The recommended title for most implementations.

This is usually the same as the canonical title, but editorializes a bit by trimming out things like "Oracle 15" in some Ironsworn oracles (because *nobody* remembers it as "Oracle 15").

If you need the shortest possible name, see {@link Title.Short} instead.
Standard.title: Standard

Title.description:
The title of the source.

For 'canonical' content, use one of the enumerated `SourceTitle` strings.

For 3rd-party content (including homebrew) that's been released as part of a titled document, use the title of that document (e.g. "Steelforged", "Ironsmith").

If the source has no particular title (for instance, it's a single custom element in a VTT implementation), use "Custom".
Title.title: Title

Authors.description: The author(s) of this item. For 'canonical' content, this one's usually pretty obvious ðŸ˜‰ However, it's included so that homebrew content can use the same interface/schema.
Authors.title: Authors

Date.description: The 6-number date string formatted as `MMDDYY`. Relevant only during Starforged development; it will be deprecated once the game is released.
Date.title: Date

Page.description: The page on which the item appears most prominently in the source material (if it's in a format that uses page numbers).
Page.title: Page

Url.description: The URL where the source material is available.
Url.title: Url

License.description: The URL pointing to the license which this content falls under.
License.title: License

Text.description:
A markdown string containing the primary trigger text for this move.

Secondary triggers (for specific stats or uses of an asset ability) are described in `Options`.
Text.title: Text

By.description:
Information on who can trigger this item. Used mainly by asset abilities, some of which can trigger from an Ally's move.

If unspecified, assume `Ally` is `false` and `Player` is `true`.
By.title: By

$id.description: The item's unique string ID. Any object that contains a localizable user-facing string *must* have this key.
$id.title: $id

Using.description: The stat(s) or progress track(s) that may be rolled with this move trigger option.
Using.title: Using

Text.description: The item's rules text as a markdown string.
Text.title: Text

$id.description: The item's unique string ID. Any object that contains a localizable user-facing string *must* have this key.
$id.title: $id

Method.description: The method used to choose the stat or track in the `Using` array.
Method.title: Method

Roll type.description: Whether this option is an action roll or progress roll.
Roll type.title: Roll type

Label.description: The user-facing text label of this item.
Label.title: Label

$id.description: The item's unique string ID. Any object that contains a localizable user-facing string *must* have this key.
$id.title: $id

Label.description: The user-facing text label of this item.
Label.title: Label

Value.description: The numeric value to be used as +stat when making an Action Roll.
Value.title: Value

$id.description: The item's unique string ID. Any object that contains a localizable user-facing string *must* have this key.
$id.title: $id

RollMethod.description: The stat(s) or progress track(s) that may be rolled with the parent move trigger option.
RollMethod.title: RollMethod

Text.description: The item's rules text as a markdown string.
Text.title: Text

Custom stat.description: Defines a custom stat, if one is included in this object's `With` array.
Custom stat.title: Custom stat

$id.description: The item's unique string ID. Any object that contains a localizable user-facing string *must* have this key.
$id.title: $id

Label.title: Label

Player.description: Whether the player character who owns this item can trigger it. Unsurprisingly, this is usually true, but there's a few exceptions: see *Starforged's* LOYALIST asset for an example.
Player.title: Player

Ally.description: Whether an Ally (a player character other than the owner) can trigger this item. This is usually false, but there's several exceptions among asset abilities.
Ally.title: Ally

$id.description: The item's unique string ID. Any object that contains a localizable user-facing string *must* have this key.
$id.title: $id

Text.description: The item's rules text as a markdown string.
Text.title: Text

In control.description: Whether this outcome leaves the player character in control (Starforged) or with initiative (Ironsworn) or not. If unspecified, assume that it's `true` on a Strong Hit, and `false` on a Weak Hit or Miss.
In control.title: In control

Count as.description: Count this roll as another roll outcome, e.g. "Count a weak hit as a miss"
Count as.title: Count as

Suggestions.description:
Describes "non-canonical" suggestions for game content related to the parent item.

These are intended be offered as convenient shortcuts for the user (for instance, including a menu dropdown for rolling on suggested tables); having them roll automatically is **not recommended** for most projects.

These can be safely ignored if that functionality is not desired.
Suggestions.title: Suggestions

Suggestions_1.description:
Describes "non-canonical" suggestions for game content related to the parent item.

These are intended be offered as convenient shortcuts for the user (for instance, including a menu dropdown for rolling on suggested tables); having them roll automatically is **not recommended** for most projects.

These can be safely ignored if that functionality is not desired.
Suggestions_1.title: Suggestions_1

Game objects.description: Suggested game objects and their parameters.
Game objects.title: Game objects

Oracle rolls.description: Suggested oracle rolls, by table ID. Multiples of the same ID can be used to indicate that multiple rolls should be made.
Oracle rolls.title: Oracle rolls

GameObject.description: Describes a game object, with optional required parameters (for example, a specific Location result).
GameObject.title: GameObject

Attributes.description: A list of attribute keys, and values of those keys that satisfy the requirements.
Attributes.title: Attributes

Display.description: Interface for data relevant to an item's display/rendering.
Display.title: Display

Display_1.description: Interface for data relevant to an item's display/rendering.
Display_1.title: Display_1

Icon.description: A URL pointing to a single SVG icon.
Icon.title: Icon

Images.description: An array of URLs pointing to one or more WEBP images.
Images.title: Images

Color.description: A hex color associated with this item, for use as e.g. an accent color in its display.
Color.title: Color

Canonical.description:
The title of this item, which here is defined as the associated header text *exactly* as it appears on the page.

For items that represent a single table column, this is the label that appears at the top of the column.

Use this title if you want high fidelity to the book. For most interactive UX, it's recommended to use {@link Title.Standard} instead.
Canonical.title: Canonical

Short.description:
The shortest title for this item that remains distinct amongst its siblings.

Unless you're very pressed for space, most UX should use {@link Title.Standard} instead.
Short.title: Short

Standard.description:
The recommended title for most implementations.

This is usually the same as the canonical title, but editorializes a bit by trimming out things like "Oracle 15" in some Ironsworn oracles (because *nobody* remembers it as "Oracle 15").

If you need the shortest possible name, see {@link Title.Short} instead.
Standard.title: Standard

Source.description: Interface representing data on this item's source. For 'canonical' content, this is usually a book with numbered pages, but it might also be a link to a web site.
Source.title: Source

Title.description:
The title of the source.

For 'canonical' content, use one of the enumerated `SourceTitle` strings.

For 3rd-party content (including homebrew) that's been released as part of a titled document, use the title of that document (e.g. "Steelforged", "Ironsmith").

If the source has no particular title (for instance, it's a single custom element in a VTT implementation), use "Custom".
Title.title: Title

Authors.description: The author(s) of this item. For 'canonical' content, this one's usually pretty obvious ðŸ˜‰ However, it's included so that homebrew content can use the same interface/schema.
Authors.title: Authors

Date.description: The 6-number date string formatted as `MMDDYY`. Relevant only during Starforged development; it will be deprecated once the game is released.
Date.title: Date

Page.description: The page on which the item appears most prominently in the source material (if it's in a format that uses page numbers).
Page.title: Page

Url.description: The URL where the source material is available.
Url.title: Url

License.description: The URL pointing to the license which this content falls under.
License.title: License
